item.title: Defense Contractor Scheduled to Change Plea in Navy Bribery Case
item.description: Leonard Glenn Francis is set to appear at a change-of-plea hearing on Thursday in federal court in San Diego. He previously pleaded not guilty to conspiracy in the case.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Soldier Kills Palestinian Suspected in Theft
item.description: An Israeli soldier fatally wounded a Palestinian on Wednesday in a confrontation over an attempt to steal a vehicle in the occupied West Bank, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Moves Five Yemenis From Guantánamo
item.description: The transfers came one day after several Republican senators proposed legislation that would place a moratorium on the release of most of the prisoners held at Guantánamo.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Iran Charges, and Will Try, Jason Rezaian, Washington Post Reporter
item.description: Iran’s official news agency said that Mr. Rezaian would be tried in a Revolutionary Court, although it did not specify the charges against him.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Jason Rezaian, a correspondent for The Washington Post.

item.title: Crisis in France Is Seen as Sign of Chronic Ills
item.description: After the Paris attacks, appeals for unity have hardly penetrated the sense of isolation, even siege, felt in cities like Vaulx-en-Velin.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM B. ELLICK and LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market near the Cité des Bosquets housing complex in Clichy-sous-Bois, a suburb of Paris largely populated by Muslims.

item.title: Attack Raises Questions on Roots of Muslim Objection to Image-Making
item.description: While many Muslims were upset by the caricatures of Muhammad in Charlie Hebdo, the origins of their objection to visual depictions of the prophet and holy persons of any faith are far from clear.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Criticism From Hong Kong’s Leader, Publisher Raises Book’s Print Run
item.description: An article by Brian Leung urging greater autonomy for Hong Kong prompted a stern warning from the territory’s government leader on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Hong Kong's chief executive, Leung Chun-ying, seen on a screen on Wednesday after his annual policy address.

item.title: Readers in Europe Respond to the Paris Attacks
item.description: The New York Times asked readers to share their experiences before and after the attacks on the Charlie Hebdo offices and a kosher grocery store last week.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial on Rue Nicolas Appert near Charlie Hebdo headquarters in eastern Paris.

item.title: Court Takes Paternity Suit Against Spain’s Ex-King
item.description: Juan Carlos’s abdication last year opened him to a paternity challenge.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Disputed Claims Over Qaeda Role in Paris Attacks
item.description: A fuller portrait of the Kouachi brothers has emerged as an international effort is focused on determining who may have been behind the attack on Charlie Hebdo, and what direct role terror organizations may have had in ordering the assault.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Rashid al-Dhaheri, a Precocious Driver at 6, Builds a Following in the United Arab Emirates
item.description: Rashid al-Dhaheri, who became enamored of motorsports after attending a Formula One race with his father, has been winning youth go-kart races and building a following in the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rashid al-Dhaheri and his racing kart in Abu Dhabi. Known as Little Alonso, after the racer Fernando Alonso, he is seen as the region’s great driving hope.

item.title: The Media Equation: Flocking to Buy Charlie Hebdo, Citizens Signal Their Support of Free Speech
item.description: The sentiment that drove the sales probably had less to do with those messages and more to do with the impulse to preserve a world in which the speech of the many cannot be held hostage by a few.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CARR
item.media:description: The new issue of the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo being prepared for delivery. French distributors said the initial printing of three million copies had been increased.

item.title: Robust Demand and Renewed Criticism as Charlie Hebdo Quickly Returns
item.description: The newspaper returned with a depiction of the Prophet Muhammad on its cover, and, in some places, vendors reported that it had sold out before daybreak.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Parisians lined up Wednesday morning to buy the first edition of Charlie Hebdo since a terrorist attack on the magazine’s office.

item.title: Devil May Be in the Details on European Central Bank Bond-Buying
item.description: A widely expected stimulus program will be a test of whether the institution and its president can walk a fine political line and show their resolve.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, with the bank's Governing Council. A majority of the council appears to favor broad-based bond buying.

item.title: Video Feature: Malaysian Muslims Travel to Syria to Fight Assad
item.description: A video about one of several dozen Malaysians whose faith has led them to take up arms against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By POH SI TENG

item.title: Fearing ‘Total Chaos’ in Libya, U.N. Plans New Peace Talks
item.description: The talks, aimed at reaching a political settlement, are seen as a last chance to end fighting that has plunged the country into deepening insecurity and economic chaos.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: World Briefing: Haiti: Broad Uncertainty as New Premier Takes Office
item.description: A new prime minister has taken office in Haiti as the country enters a period of political uncertainty after the dissolution of Parliament because of a stalemate between lawmakers and the president.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Sri Lanka: Prisoners Freed in Honor of Pope’s Visit
item.description: Sri Lanka released 572 prisoners and reduced terms for others on Wednesday in connection with Pope Francis’ visit and his proclamation of the country’s first saint.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Ban Rak Thai Journal: In Remote Thai Villages, Legacy of China’s Lost Army Endures
item.description: Dozens of villages in northern Thailand are home to veterans and descendants of a unit of the Nationalist Army, which lost to Mao in 1949.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Veterans of what is known as China's Lost Army, a unit of the Kuomintang army, and and their descendants still live Mae Aw, a village in northwestern Thailand.

item.title: Resignation of President Will Test Italy’s Premier
item.description: The intense maneuvering after Italy’s president, Giorgio Napolitano, announced his resignation may become a minefield for Prime Minister Matteo Renzi.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
